overview_of_class:
How can economies grow rich? And how may economies fail to grow rich? These are fundamental questions in economics. Even Adam Smith alluded to them in the title of his book, "The Wealth of Nations." These broad questions are the main focus of this course. No one can claim to have the answer to these difficult questions. However, economic theories can inform us on some important determinants of long-run growth patterns and development performances. In this course, we will cover some of the leading theories proposed to understand different aspects of long-run growth and development: Saving and capital accumulation, technological change, structural change, demographic transition, income distribution, imperfect credit markets, etc.

Detailed Contents of the Class: 1. Facts and Measurement 2. Traditional Theories of Economic Growth (Harrod-Domar, Solow) 3. New Growth Theories (Human Capital, Endogenous Technological Progress) 4. History, Expectations and Development (Complementarities, Increasing Returns and Poverty traps) 5. Credit Markets (Alternative micro underpinnings and related theories) 6. Inequality and Growth (Measurement, Kuznets Hypothesis, Interaction with Credit Markets) 7. Population Growth and Economic Development (Demographic Transition, Unified Growth Theory) 8. International Linkages: Trade and Financial Markets (time permitting) 9. Political Economy of Growth (time permitting)
name: Economic Growth & Development
